turns.content: How tall is Hadrian's Wall and what materials were used in its construction?

Hadrian's Wall was approximately 3.7 meters (12 feet) tall. The wall was constructed using a variety of materials including stone, turf, and wood. The wall was primarily made of stone, which was quarried locally and laid in a regular pattern using mortar. The wall was built with a wide base and tapered towards the top to provide stability and prevent it from collapsing under its own weight. The wall also had several defensive features including milecastles, turrets, and a ditch on the northern side.
Wow, it's impressive how they were able to construct such a massive wall using such primitive materials. Do you know how long it took to build?

The exact duration it took to build Hadrian's Wall is not known, but historians estimate that it took around six years to construct from 122-128 AD. Keep in mind that the construction of the wall was not a continuous process, it was done in phases, with different sections of the wall being built at different times. The construction was done by a mix of Roman soldiers and local laborers, using primitive tools and techniques. Despite the challenges faced during the construction, the wall would remain an impressive feat of engineering for centuries to come.

The wall is located in Northern England and stretches for 73 miles (117 km) from the River Tyne in the east to the Solway Firth in the west. The area surrounding the wall is also rich in history and offers visitors the chance to explore ancient Roman ruins, historic castles, and stunning landscapes.
